questions.text: Proteins are mainly formed in soma and then transported toward the axon terminal with the help of various types of molecular motors. All the following proteins are known as molecular motors, because of their involvement in intracellular trafficking except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Keratin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kinesin and dynein are the primary molecular motors responsible for anterograde and retrograde transport in neurons. Keratin is not a molecular motor and does not contribute to axoplasmic flow.
  • ➤ anterograde and retrograde transport
  • ➤ Keratin is not a molecular motor and does not contribute to axoplasmic flow.

questions.text: In the context of endocrine disorders, the abundant presence of smooth endoplasmic reticulum within endocrine cells plays a pivotal role. A prolific system of smooth endoplasmic reticulum is present in endocrine cell acting through which one of the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Steroids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) is primarily involved in steroid hormone synthesis in endocrine cells, distinguishing it from the rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER), which is responsible for protein synthesis .
  • ➤ smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER)
  • ➤ steroid hormone synthesis
  • ➤ rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER), which is responsible for protein synthesis

questions.text: In a patient with gastrointestinal symptoms, the dysfunction of which cellular structure, associated with the transmembrane protein Claudin, could potentially lead to altered permeability and paracellular transport?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tight junctions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tight junctions , composed of Claudin and Occludin , regulate paracellular transport and are crucial for maintaining gastrointestinal barrier integrity . Dysfunction of tight junctions can lead to increased intestinal permeability , contributing to various gastrointestinal disorders .
  • ➤ Tight junctions
  • ➤ Claudin
  • ➤ Occludin
  • ➤ paracellular transport
  • ➤ gastrointestinal barrier integrity
  • ➤ intestinal permeability
  • ➤ gastrointestinal disorders

questions.text: In a patient undergoing cancer treatment, which protein associated with Microtubule Organizing Centers (MTOCs) becomes a key target due to its crucial role in cell division, making it a promising target for chemotherapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tubulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tubulin is the key protein forming microtubules , which are essential for mitotic spindle formation during cell division. Chemotherapy drugs target tubulin to prevent uncontrolled proliferation of cancer cells , making it a crucial target in cancer treatment.
  • ➤ Tubulin is the key protein forming microtubules
  • ➤ mitotic spindle formation
  • ➤ Chemotherapy drugs target tubulin to prevent uncontrolled proliferation of cancer cells

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a history of progressive weakness and sensory loss in the limbs. Nerve conduction studies indicate a demyelinating pattern. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the gene producing subunits of gap junctions. These clinical and genetic findings point towards Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT), a hereditary neuropathy affecting peripheral nerves. Which subunits of the cellular structures are impacted by the genetic mutation in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Connexons

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMTX) is caused by mutations in Connexin 32 (Cx32), a key protein in gap junctions. Connexons, the structural units of gap junctions, play a crucial role in Schwann cell function and peripheral nerve myelination.

questions.text: In a patient with a rare genetic disorder affecting cellular transport, dysfunction of a specific protein clathrin is suspected. What cellular process, crucial for nutrient uptake and receptor-mediated signaling, is primarily associated with this protein? The protein clathrin is primarily involved in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Endocytosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clathrin is a crucial protein in receptor-mediated endocytosis , forming clathrin-coated vesicles to internalize nutrients, receptors, and signaling molecules. It plays a key role in cellular transport and membrane trafficking , making it essential for various physiological and pathological processes.
  • ➤ Clathrin is a crucial protein in receptor-mediated endocytosis
  • ➤ cellular transport and membrane trafficking
  • ➤ physiological and pathological

questions.text: In molecular biological research, the effects of different glycosides on the sodium - potassium pump were studied. Where will be the binding site of the plant derived glycoside ouabain on this pump?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Extracellular

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ouabain binds to the extracellular domain of the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase, inhibiting its function and disrupting ion transport. This inhibition increases intracellular Na⁺, indirectly leading to increased intracellular Ca²⁺, which enhances cardiac contractility—a mechanism used in heart failure treatment with cardiac glycosides like digoxin.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male comes to OPD with complain of weight loss despite overeating, continuous thirst sensation and increased urinary frequency. The physician advised investigation one of which was glucose tolerance test. Glucose is absorbed in intestine by-
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Secondary active transport

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose is absorbed in the intestine by SGLT1 via secondary active transport , which relies on the sodium gradient maintained by Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase .
  • ➤ SGLT1 via secondary active transport
  • ➤ Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase

questions.text: The water molecules move from the capillaries to interstitium by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Filtration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Water moves from capillaries to the interstitium via filtration, driven by hydrostatic pressure. This passive process does not require ATP or carrier proteins and is a key mechanism in fluid exchange between blood and tissues.

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane represented below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Facilitated diffusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Facilitated diffusion is a passive transport process where carrier proteins help move molecules across the membrane along their concentration gradient without ATP. It differs from active transport, which requires energy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: Sodium channels during nerve impulse generation - negative feedback

options.label: D
options.text: LH surge during menstruation - positive feedback

questions.correct_answer: B. Sodium channels during nerve impulse generation - negative feedback
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sodium channels during nerve impulse generation - negative feedback

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Hodgkin cycle (positive feedback loop) amplifies sodium channel activation during action potential generation, whereas hormonal regulation of GnRH, FSH, and estrogen typically follows negative feedback. The LH surge during ovulation is a key example of positive feedback in the endocrine system.

questions.text: All the following statements regarding the fluid compartments are correct except?

options.label: A
options.text: Plasma accounts for 25% of body weight

options.label: B
options.text: ICF constitutes for 40% of the body weight

options.label: C
options.text: Water constitutes 60% of the body weight

questions.correct_answer: A. Plasma accounts for 25% of body weight
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Plasma accounts for 25% of body weight

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The 60-40-20 rule explains the distribution of body fluids, where plasma accounts for only 5% of total body weight. Misinterpreting this as 25% is incorrect.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old healthy male, the different body fluid compartments were measured. Which of the following can be used to measure his interstitial fluid volume?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thiosulfate and Evans Blue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Interstitial fluid volume is measured indirectly using a combination of an ECF marker (thiosulfate) and a plasma marker (Evans Blue). The interstitial fluid volume is derived by subtracting plasma volume from extracellular fluid volume.

questions.text: Assertion : In absolute refractory period, the nerve cannot be stimulated even with a strong stimulus Reason : Majority of the sodium channels are in inactivated state during the early part of the refractory period Identify the correct statement from the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion statement is incorrect, but the reason statement is correct

options.label: D
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are incorrect

questions.correct_answer: A. Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The absolute refractory period occurs because most voltage-gated Na⁺ channels are inactivated, preventing any new action potential from occurring, even with a strong stimulus.

questions.text: In a 45-year-old patient with weakness and sensory disturbances in the right arm and leg, nerve conduction studies are performed. Which of the following nerve fiber-function pairings is incorrect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aɣ - temperature

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aɣ fibers are purely motor fibers involved in muscle spindle function and do not carry temperature sensation. Temperature sensation is transmitted by Aδ and C fibers.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a complaint of weakness and numbness in his right arm and hand after a night of heavy drinking and falling asleep with his arm draped over the back of a chair. He reports difficulty in moving his fingers and gripping objects. To assess the condition, the physician discusses the order of susceptibility of nerve fibers to pressure effects, which of the following accurately represents the order of susceptibility of nerve fibers to in the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C < B < A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of nerve compression (such as Saturday Night Palsy), A fibers (motor and sensory) are affected first, followed by B fibers (autonomic), and finally C fibers (pain and temperature). The order of susceptibility is C < B < A.

questions.text: All the following statements regarding the Type I skeletal muscle fibers are correct except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fast Fatigue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type I muscle fibers are slow oxidative fibers that are fatigue-resistant, small in size, red due to high myoglobin, and have high oxidative capacity. They do not fatigue quickly, making them suited for endurance activities.
  • ➤ Types of skeletal muscle fibers:
  • ➤ Types of skeletal muscle fibers:

questions.text: Assertion : Increased myosin ATPase activity facilitates the binding of myosin to actin in smooth muscle Reason : Myosin light chain phosphatase causes phosphorylation of myosin during smooth muscle contraction Which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion statement is correct, but the reason statement is incorrect

options.label: D
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are incorrect

questions.correct_answer: C. The assertion statement is correct, but the reason statement is incorrect
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Smooth muscle contraction is regulated by myosin light chain kinase (MLCK), which phosphorylates myosin, allowing it to interact with actin. Myosin ATPase activity enables cross-bridge cycling. Myosin light chain phosphatase (MLCP) dephosphorylates myosin, leading to muscle relaxation.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the True statement regarding Skeletal muscle? Extracellular Ca2+ is not important for contraction. Ca2+ released mainly from Mitochondria. Ca2+ released from sarcoplasmic reticulum. Voltage gated Ca2+ channels on sarcolemma has no role in EC coupling.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Skeletal muscle contraction relies on intracellular Ca²⁺ from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, not extracellular Ca²⁺. Voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels (DHPR) on the sarcolemma do not allow Ca²⁺ influx but are essential for activating RyR1 and initiating Ca²⁺ release from the SR.

questions.text: A 44-year male presented to the general medicine OPD with a history of muscle weakness in the lower limbs, difficulty in walking and severe fatigability. He was admitted and nerve conduction study was done. On repetitive motor nerve stimulation, the muscle strength was found to be increased. What would be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lambert-Eaton syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lambert-Eaton Syndrome is a pre-synaptic neuromuscular disorder caused by autoantibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs) . A key diagnostic feature is incremental response to repetitive nerve stimulation , differentiating it from Myasthenia Gravis, which has a decremental response .
  • ➤ pre-synaptic neuromuscular disorder
  • ➤ autoantibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs)
  • ➤ incremental response to repetitive nerve stimulation
  • ➤ decremental response

questions.text: The dihydropyridine receptors located in the Cardiac muscle are?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Voltage gated calcium channels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dihydropyridine receptors (DHPR) in cardiac muscle are voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs) that allow extracellular calcium to enter, leading to calcium-induced calcium release (CICR) via ryanodine receptors (RYR). This mechanism is crucial for cardiac muscle contraction .
  • ➤ voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs)
  • ➤ calcium-induced calcium release (CICR)
  • ➤ cardiac muscle contraction

questions.text: In a 42-year-old male, during the clinical examination, his blood pressure was found to be 132/82 mm Hg, heart rate was 70/min and respiratory rate was 18/min. What would be the stroke volume in this patient if his cardiac output was 4.9 L?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) 70 mL

questions.text: During the period of isovolumetric relaxation of the ventricles, which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Volume remains the same, the pressure decreases

options.label: B
options.text: Pressure remains the same, the volume decreases

options.label: C
options.text: Volume remains the same, pressure increases or decreases

options.label: D
options.text: Both volume and pressure remain the same

questions.correct_answer: A. Volume remains the same, the pressure decreases
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Volume remains the same, the pressure decreases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During isovolumetric relaxation , the ventricular volume remains unchanged while the pressure decreases as the myocardium relaxes. This phase occurs after ventricular systole and before the AV valves open for ventricular filling.
  • ➤ isovolumetric relaxation
  • ➤ ventricular volume remains unchanged while the pressure decreases

questions.text: The following heart sound marked (purple arrow) in the picture will be heard because of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Closure of semilunar valves

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The second heart sound (S2) is caused by the closure of the semilunar valves at the end of ventricular systole.

questions.text: In a 60-year-old male, the echocardiography revealed the end systolic volume to be 70 mL and the end diastolic volume to be 130 mL. If his cardiac output is 5L/min, what would be the stroke volume in this patient?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) 60L

questions.text: Assertion: When a person changes his position from standing to lying, the stroke volume will be decreased Reason: The venous return will be increased during lying position Which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion statement is incorrect, but the reason statement is correct

options.label: D
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are incorrect

questions.correct_answer: C. The assertion statement is incorrect, but the reason statement is correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The assertion statement is incorrect, but the reason statement is correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When changing from standing to lying down, venous return increases due to reduced gravitational pooling of blood. This leads to increased preload and stroke volume via the Frank-Starling mechanism. Thus, stroke volume increases, not decreases.

questions.text: Statement A: 40% of emptying of blood from the ventricles will take place in the first third of the period of ejection Statement B: The last-third of the ejection period is termed as rapid ejection phase. Which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The statement A is true, the statement B is false

options.label: B
options.text: The statement A is false, the statement B is true

options.label: C
options.text: Both the statements A and B are true

options.label: D
options.text: Both the statements A and B are false

questions.correct_answer: D. Both the statements A and B are false
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both the statements A and B are false

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ventricular ejection phase consists of rapid ejection (first ⅔) and slow ejection (last ⅓) . The majority (66-80%) of blood is ejected in the first third , while the last third is known as the slow ejection phase, not rapid ejection.
  • ➤ ventricular ejection phase
  • ➤ rapid ejection (first ⅔) and slow ejection (last ⅓)
  • ➤ majority (66-80%)
  • ➤ first third
  • ➤ last third is known as the slow ejection phase, not rapid ejection.

questions.text: In the electrocardiogram, if the electric potentials of two bipolar limb leads (Lead I and Lead III) are known, the electric potential of the third limb lead (Lead II) can be determined by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lead I + Lead III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Einthoven’s Law states that in a standard ECG, the sum of Lead I and Lead III equals Lead II. This relationship helps in calculating missing lead values if two leads are known.

questions.text: Assertion: The Sino-atrial node will serve as the pacemaker of the cardiac impulse Reason: The Sino-atrial node is capable of generating impulses at higher rates compared to other components of the cardiac conduction system Which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion statement is incorrect, but the reason statement is correct

options.label: D
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are incorrect

questions.correct_answer: A. Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct; the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The SA node is the natural pacemaker of the heart because it has the highest intrinsic rate of depolarization (60–100 bpm), which suppresses other pacemaker sites. The AV node provides a conduction delay to allow proper ventricular filling, while the Purkinje fibers have the fastest conduction velocity for efficient ventricular contraction.

questions.text: The Phase 3 of Action potential is due to which one of the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) K+ efflux

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phase 3 of the action potential is due to K⁺ efflux through voltage-gated potassium channels, leading to repolarization of the membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following are concerned with the maximum percentage of blood volume in the vascular tree?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Veins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Veins contain the majority of blood volume (~60-70%) in the vascular system due to their high compliance, making them capacitance vessels. Arteries serve as conduit vessels, capillaries function in exchange, and the aorta acts as a windkessel vessel to maintain pressure.

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents:

options.label: A
options.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.correct_answer: A. Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The C wave of the JVP represents the tricuspid valve bulging into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction due to the increased right ventricular pressure.
  • ➤ C wave of the JVP represents the tricuspid valve bulging into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.text: Cardiologist suspecting Exertional Angina in a 52-year man. He advised the patient to get an investigation done i.e., stress Echocardiography to check the blood flow. In which of the following phases does the left ventricular sub endocardium receive blood supply through the coronary arteries?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) After T wave

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The left ventricular subendocardium receives the majority of its blood supply during diastole , which occurs after the T wave on an ECG. This is because coronary artery perfusion is restricted during systole due to myocardial contraction and vessel compression.
  • ➤ left ventricular subendocardium receives the majority of its blood supply during diastole
  • ➤ after the T wave

questions.text: All the following are true about myocardium except:

options.label: A
options.text: Increase Sympathetic activity causes positive ionotropic and negative lusitropic effect

options.label: B
options.text: Increase Sympathetic activity causes positive ionotropic and positive lusitropic effect

options.label: C
options.text: Lusitropic effect is mediated by cAMP dependent pathway.

options.label: D
options.text: Increase Ca 2+ uptake from ECF to cytoplasm decreases lucitropy in the absence of sympathetic stimulation

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase Sympathetic activity causes positive ionotropic and negative lusitropic effect
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sympathetic stimulation enhances both myocardial contraction (positive inotropy) and relaxation (positive lusitropy) via the cAMP-PKA pathway . Phospholamban inhibition allows faster Ca²⁺ reuptake into the SR , improving relaxation.
  • ➤ enhances both myocardial contraction (positive inotropy) and relaxation (positive lusitropy)
  • ➤ cAMP-PKA pathway
  • ➤ Ca²⁺ reuptake into the SR

questions.text: Left and right ventricular chambers work for systemic and pulmonary circulations respectively. Which one of the following characteristics is most similar in the systemic and pulmonary circulations?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Preload

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The preload (end-diastolic volume) is nearly identical in both systemic and pulmonary circulations because both ventricles receive and pump the same volume of blood per beat under normal physiological conditions.
  • ➤ preload (end-diastolic volume) is nearly identical in both systemic and pulmonary circulations
  • ➤ both ventricles receive and pump the same volume of blood per beat

questions.text: The main cause of increased blood flow to exercising muscles is:

options.label: C
options.text: Increased sympathetic discharge to peripheral vessels

questions.correct_answer: B. Vasodilatation due to local metabolites
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vasodilatation due to local metabolites

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The main cause of increased blood flow to exercising muscles is local metabolic vasodilation , driven by potassium, adenosine, CO₂, lactic acid, and temperature changes . This ensures better oxygen delivery and waste removal during exercise.
  • ➤ main cause of increased blood flow to exercising muscles is local metabolic vasodilation
  • ➤ potassium, adenosine, CO₂, lactic acid, and temperature changes

questions.text: All of the following statements about the flow of blood in a blood vessel are true, except:

options.label: A
options.text: The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the pressure difference

options.label: B
options.text: The blood flow will be directly proportional to the radius

options.label: C
options.text: The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the length

options.label: D
options.text: The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the viscosity

questions.correct_answer: A. The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the pressure difference
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the pressure difference

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Poiseuille’s Law states that blood flow is directly proportional to the pressure difference and vessel radius (r⁴) and inversely proportional to the vessel length and blood viscosity. The most critical factor affecting blood flow is the radius of the vessel.

questions.text: All the following statements are incorrect about the Reynolds number, except?

options.label: A
options.text: The turbulence will decrease with increase in Reynolds number

options.label: B
options.text: The Reynolds number is inversely proportional to the velocity

options.label: C
options.text: The Reynolds number will be decreased when the radius is increased

options.label: D
options.text: The Reynolds number is inversely proportional to the viscosity

questions.correct_answer: D. The Reynolds number is inversely proportional to the viscosity
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The Reynold number is inversely proportional to the viscosity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Reynolds number predicts whether blood flow will be laminar or turbulent. It is directly proportional to velocity and vessel diameter but inversely proportional to viscosity. Higher Reynolds number increases turbulence, while higher viscosity reduces it.

questions.text: When the radius of a blood vessel is tripled, the blood flow across the blood vessel will be increased by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 81 times

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to the Poiseuille-Hagen equation, blood flow (F) is proportional to the fourth power of the vessel radius (r⁴). A small increase in radius results in a massive increase in flow. If the radius triples, blood flow increases by 81 times (3⁴ = 81).

questions.text: The nigrostriatal projections to the striatum within the basal ganglia is associated with which neurotransmitter?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dopamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nigrostriatal pathway is a dopaminergic projection from the substantia nigra to the striatum and is essential for motor function . Degeneration of this pathway leads to Parkinson’s disease.
  • ➤ nigrostriatal pathway
  • ➤ dopaminergic
  • ➤ substantia nigra to the striatum
  • ➤ motor function
  • ➤ Degeneration of this pathway leads to Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: The following diagram shows the depth of respiration of a 45-year-old man who suffered a head injury in an automobile accident. This “crescendo decrescendo” pattern of breathing is called which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cheyne-Stokes breathing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cheyne-Stokes breathing is a periodic pattern of respiration with a crescendo-decrescendo rhythm followed by apnea. It occurs in brain injuries, strokes, heart failure, and high-altitude adaptation. It is different from Biot’s breathing (irregular) and hyperpnea (no apnea).

questions.text: When medical student were performing the amphibian experiments, they recorded a graph of a muscle contraction, in which latent period: 10ms, contraction period 40ms and relaxation period was 20ms. Calculate tetanizing frequency:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 25 Hz

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetanizing frequency is calculated as the inverse of the contraction period (in seconds). It represents the frequency at which repeated stimuli lead to sustained muscle contraction (tetany). In this case, the frequency required is 25 Hz.

questions.text: The tactile discrimination will be affected in the lesion of this ascending sensory pathway of the spinal cord?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior column

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fine touch, vibration, and proprioception are carried by the posterior column-medial lemniscus pathway. Pain, temperature, and crude touch are carried by the spinothalamic tract. Damage to the posterior column leads to loss of fine touch discrimination and proprioception.
  • ➤ Fine touch, vibration, and proprioception are carried by the posterior column-medial lemniscus pathway.
  • ➤ Pain, temperature, and crude touch are carried by the spinothalamic tract.
  • ➤ Damage to the posterior column leads to loss of fine touch discrimination and proprioception.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lecithin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS) is caused by a deficiency of pulmonary surfactant, which is primarily composed of Dipalmitoyl Phosphatidylcholine (Lecithin). This leads to alveolar collapse and impaired gas exchange, particularly in preterm infants.
  • ➤ Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS) is caused by a deficiency of pulmonary surfactant, which is primarily composed of Dipalmitoyl Phosphatidylcholine (Lecithin).
  • ➤ alveolar collapse and impaired gas exchange, particularly in preterm infants.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man inhaled as much air as possible and then expired with a maximum effort until no more air could be expired. This produced the maximum expiratory flow-volume curve shown in the following diagram. What is the forced vital capacity of this man (in litres)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 4.5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The forced vital capacity (FVC) is determined by subtracting the residual volume (RV) from total lung capacity (TLC) . In this case:
  • ➤ forced vital capacity (FVC)
  • ➤ residual volume (RV) from total lung capacity (TLC)
  • ➤ FVC=5.5L−1L=4.5L
  • ➤ Thus, the correct answer is 4.5 litres (Option D).
  • ➤ 4.5 litres (Option D).

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the given spirometry graph?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Functional residual capacity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air left in the lungs after a normal expiration, composed of Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) and Residual Volume (RV). It is also called Relaxation Volume because all respiratory muscles are at rest.

questions.text: A patient with respiratory volume of 500 mL The intra-pleural pressure measured -4 cm H 2 O before inspiration and -8 H 2 O at the end of inspiration. The pulmonary compliance of the patient is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 125 mL/cm H2O

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pulmonary compliance (C = ΔV/ΔP) measures the lung's ability to expand and is calculated as the change in lung volume per unit change in intrapleural pressure. In this case, compliance is 125 mL/cm H₂O.
  • ➤ Pulmonary compliance (C = ΔV/ΔP) measures the lung's ability to expand and is calculated as the change in lung volume per unit change in intrapleural pressure. In this case, compliance is 125 mL/cm H₂O.

questions.text: A young man goes on high altitude he starts to feel dyspnea. His Peripheral chemoreceptors respond to hypoxia using which channel?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Potassium channel

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The oxygen-sensitive potassium channel in peripheral chemoreceptors is crucial for detecting hypoxia. In low oxygen conditions, these channels close, leading to cell depolarization, calcium influx, and neurotransmitter release to stimulate breathing.
  • ➤ oxygen-sensitive potassium channel

questions.text: Closing capacity of lung is related to:

options.label: A
options.text: Small size bronchioles without cartilage in nondependent portion of lung

options.label: B
options.text: Small size bronchioles without cartilage in dependent portion of lung

options.label: C
options.text: Medium size bronchioles with cartilage in nondependent portion of lung

options.label: D
options.text: Medium size bronchioles without cartilage in dependent portion of lung

questions.correct_answer: B. Small size bronchioles without cartilage in dependent portion of lung
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Small size bronchioles without cartilage in dependent portion of lung

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Closing capacity is primarily related to the collapse of small bronchioles without cartilage in the dependent portion of the lung . This is important in conditions affecting lung compliance and aging , as airway closure can lead to ventilation-perfusion mismatch and hypoxia.
  • ➤ collapse of small bronchioles without cartilage in the dependent portion of the lung
  • ➤ lung compliance and aging

questions.text: V/Q = infinity holds true in which of the following conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus

options.label: C
options.text: When 02 and CO2 ratio is equal

options.label: D
options.text: The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Equal to dead space

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ V/Q = ∞ occurs when ventilation is present but perfusion is absent , leading to dead space ventilation . This occurs in conditions like pulmonary embolism, where alveolar dead space increases .
  • ➤ V/Q = ∞ occurs when ventilation is present but perfusion is absent
  • ➤ dead space ventilation
  • ➤ pulmonary embolism, where alveolar dead space increases

questions.text: A patient met with a road traffic accident and developed a cervical spine injury. The fracture fragment had pierced the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract. Which of the following findings is seen in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception

options.label: B
options.text: Absence of fine motor movement of fingers

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.correct_answer: C. Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?

options.label: A
options.text: Fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers.

options.label: B
options.text: Fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers.

options.label: C
options.text: Fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers.

options.label: D
options.text: Fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers.

questions.correct_answer: C. Fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Large myelinated A fibers (motor fibers) are more susceptible to pressure-related damage than small unmyelinated C fibers (sensory fibers). This explains why paresis (weakness) occurs without numbness when a nerve is compressed.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presented with slowly progressive motor weakness, nuchal rigidity, and difficulty in swallowing and carrying out day-to-day activities. A provisional diagnosis of multiple sclerosis is suspected. Which of the following cells are affected in multiple sclerosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oligodendrocytes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease that affects the CNS by targeting oligodendrocytes, leading to progressive neurological dysfunction due to loss of myelin insulation in neurons.
  • ➤ Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease that affects the CNS by targeting oligodendrocytes, leading to progressive neurological dysfunction due to loss of myelin insulation in neurons.

questions.text: A lady presents with vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Motor speech area

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The motor speech area (Broca’s area) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus (Brodmann areas 44 and 45) of the dominant hemisphere. A lesion here results in Broca’s aphasia, characterized by impaired speech production but intact comprehension.

questions.text: Which of the following pair regarding vasopressin is incorrect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vasopressin (ADH) acts via V1 (vascular smooth muscle), V2 (renal collecting ducts), and V3 (anterior pituitary) receptors . There is no V4 receptor , making option D incorrect .
  • ➤ V1 (vascular smooth muscle), V2 (renal collecting ducts), and V3 (anterior pituitary) receptors
  • ➤ no V4 receptor
  • ➤ option D incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following hormones use receptor tyrosine kinase signalling?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Insulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Receptor Tyrosine Kinase (RTK) signaling is used by insulin, growth factors (IGF-1, FGF, PDGF, EGF), and some other hormones. TSH, TRH, and MSH act via G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) pathways instead.

questions.text: All use cAMP as second messenger except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prolactin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prolactin does not use cAMP as a second messenger; instead, it operates through the JAK-STAT pathway, distinguishing it from many other hormones that rely on GPCR and cAMP signaling.
  • ➤ not
  • ➤ JAK-STAT

questions.text: Statement A: The S cells of the pancreatic islets are associated with the secretion of somatostatin. Statement B: Glucagon will be secreted from the gamma cells of the endocrine pancreas. Which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The statement A is true, the statement B is false

options.label: B
options.text: The statement A is false, the statement B is true

options.label: C
options.text: Both the statements A and B are true

options.label: D
options.text: Both the statements A and B are false

questions.correct_answer: D. Both the statements A and B are false
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both the statements A and B are false

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delta (D) cells of the pancreas secrete somatostatin . S cells of the duodenum secrete secretin . Alpha (A) cells of the pancreas secrete glucagon , while gamma (Γ) cells secrete pancreatic polypeptide .
  • ➤ Delta (D) cells of the pancreas secrete somatostatin .
  • ➤ Delta (D) cells
  • ➤ somatostatin
  • ➤ S cells of the duodenum secrete secretin .
  • ➤ S cells
  • ➤ duodenum
  • ➤ secretin
  • ➤ Alpha (A) cells of the pancreas secrete glucagon , while gamma (Γ) cells secrete pancreatic polypeptide .
  • ➤ Alpha (A) cells
  • ➤ glucagon
  • ➤ gamma (Γ) cells
  • ➤ pancreatic polypeptide

questions.text: Which of the following will decrease the secretion of insulin? Hypokalemia Acetylcholine Glucagon Fasting
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypokalemia and fasting decrease insulin secretion. Acetylcholine (parasympathetic stimulation) and glucagon increase insulin secretion.
  • ➤ Hypokalemia and fasting decrease insulin secretion.
  • ➤ Hypokalemia
  • ➤ fasting
  • ➤ Acetylcholine (parasympathetic stimulation) and glucagon increase insulin secretion.
  • ➤ Acetylcholine
  • ➤ glucagon

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with hematemesis has heart- burn and stomach pain. An endoscopy shows inflammation involving the gastric body and antrum as well as a small gastric ulcer. Biopsies were positive for H. pylori. H. pylori damages the gastric mucosa primarily by increasing mucosal levels of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ammonium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ H. pylori damages the gastric mucosa primarily by producing urease , which increases ammonium levels. This disrupts the mucosal barrier, leading to inflammation and ulcer formation.
  • ➤ urease
  • ➤ ammonium

questions.text: A 32-year-old female came to the OPD for follow up of vitamin B12 deficiency Anemia which is developed post-gastrectomy. Intrinsic factor protects the vitamin B12 from degradation in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Small intestine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intrinsic factor protects vitamin B12 in the small intestine , particularly in the duodenum , by forming a complex that prevents degradation and allows for absorption in the terminal ileum .
  • ➤ vitamin B12 in the small intestine
  • ➤ duodenum
  • ➤ terminal ileum

questions.text: The migrating motor complex in humans:

options.label: A
options.text: Occurs only in the small intestine.

options.label: B
options.text: Requires an intact intrinsic nervous system for coordinated propagation.

options.label: C
options.text: Is the result of food-mediated distension of the small intestine.

options.label: D
options.text: Mixes intestinal contents with bile and the digestive enzymes.

questions.correct_answer: B. Requires an intact intrinsic nervous system for coordinated propagation.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Requires an intact intrinsic nervous system for coordinated propagation.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Migrating Motor Complex (MMC) is a cyclic peristaltic movement that occurs between meals to clear residual food and bacteria from the stomach and small intestine. It requires an intact intrinsic nervous system (myenteric plexus) for coordination and is not triggered by food ingestion .
  • ➤ Migrating Motor Complex (MMC)
  • ➤ between meals
  • ➤ requires an intact intrinsic nervous system (myenteric plexus) for coordination
  • ➤ not triggered by food ingestion

questions.text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Enterogastric

questions.text: Most common cause of iron deficiency anemia is lack of dietary intake of iron. Iron is transported from enterocyte to capillary through:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ferroprotein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron is transported from the intestinal lumen to the enterocyte by DMT1 , but it is exported from the enterocyte to the capillary via ferroportin .
  • ➤ intestinal lumen to the enterocyte by DMT1
  • ➤ enterocyte to the capillary via ferroportin

questions.text: A 34-year male came to OPD with complain of heartburn from last 2 months, he further says the acidity increases after eating so he developed anorexia. Which one of the following does not increase secretion of gastric acid?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Secretin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Secretin inhibits gastric acid secretion by stimulating bicarbonate secretion and reducing gastrin release, whereas acetylcholine, histamine, and gastrin increase acid secretion.

questions.text: Which one of the following does not have a Na+ I- transporter?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pituitary

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Na⁺/I⁻ symporter (NIS) is present in the thyroid, salivary glands, placenta, and mammary glands , but not in the pituitary gland .
  • ➤ Na⁺/I⁻ symporter (NIS)
  • ➤ thyroid, salivary glands, placenta, and mammary glands
  • ➤ not in the pituitary gland

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present, and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) SGLT1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ORS works by utilizing the Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporter 1 (SGLT1) in the small intestine, which co-transports glucose and sodium, promoting water absorption. This is the fundamental mechanism behind the effectiveness of ORS in dehydration therapy.
  • ➤ ORS works by utilizing the Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporter 1 (SGLT1) in the small intestine, which co-transports glucose and sodium, promoting water absorption. This is the fundamental mechanism behind the effectiveness of ORS in dehydration therapy.
  • ➤ ORS contains Na+ and glucose which facilitates glucose absorption through SGLT 1 (Sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter - 1).

questions.text: The hypothalamus and fat tissues also play an important role in the regulation of energy metabolism Leptin acts by increasing the activity of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Αlpha MSH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leptin increases the activity of α-MSH , which promotes satiety and reduces food intake . At the same time, it inhibits AgRP and Neuropeptide Y , which are responsible for increasing hunger.
  • ➤ increases the activity of α-MSH
  • ➤ satiety
  • ➤ reduces food intake
  • ➤ inhibits AgRP and Neuropeptide Y

questions.text: The morning after a rock concert, a 20-year-old college student notices difficulty hearing his professor during lecture. The physician at the Student Health Center suspects possible damage to his hair cells by the loud music. Depolarization of the hair cells in the cochlea is caused primarily by the flow of which of the following?

options.label: C
options.text: Cl– out of the hair cell

questions.correct_answer: A. K+ into the hair cell
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) K+ into the hair cell

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hair cells in the cochlea depolarize due to K⁺ influx from the potassium-rich endolymph , which is secreted by the stria vascularis . This potassium influx occurs through mechanically gated channels in the stereocilia , initiating the hearing signal.
  • ➤ K⁺ influx
  • ➤ potassium-rich endolymph
  • ➤ stria vascularis
  • ➤ mechanically gated channels
  • ➤ stereocilia

questions.text: A 57-year-old patient recovers from COVID 19 infection, but still complains of no improvement in Smell and taste sensation. Bitter taste is mediated by action of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) G protein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bitter taste is detected through G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) , specifically T2R receptors that activate gustducin , leading to taste signal transduction.
  • ➤ G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs)
  • ➤ T2R receptors
  • ➤ gustducin

questions.text: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after a traffic accident causing a traumatic brain injury. Within several hours he begins eating objects such as paper, is unable to maintain attention, and displays increased sexual activity. He is diagnosed with Klüver-Bucy syndrome. A diagnostic MRI is ordered to confirm bilateral lesions of which of the following regions of the brain?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Temporal lobe

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Klüver-Bucy syndrome is caused by bilateral lesions of the temporal lobe, particularly the amygdala , and is characterized by hyperorality, hypermetamorphosis, hypersexuality, and emotional blunting .
  • ➤ bilateral lesions of the temporal lobe, particularly the amygdala
  • ➤ hyperorality, hypermetamorphosis, hypersexuality, and emotional blunting

questions.text: In skin the somatosensory receptors work as a transducer, which convert various types of sensation into electrical energy and sent the signals to the brain. One of them is onion shaped corpuscles present in dermis. It detects which one of the following properties?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vibration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pacinian corpuscles (onion-shaped) are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors that detect deep pressure and high-frequency vibrations .
  • ➤ Pacinian corpuscles
  • ➤ rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors
  • ➤ deep pressure and high-frequency vibrations

questions.text: A 32-year male patient comes to the OPD with the complain of diffuse pain in abdomen from last 3 hours. While history taking, he tells the attending physician that he ate street food last night. This sensation is transmitted by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C fibers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Visceral pain (diffuse, dull, poorly localized pain) is transmitted by unmyelinated C fibers , whereas sharp, localized pain is carried by A delta fibers .
  • ➤ Visceral pain (diffuse, dull, poorly localized pain) is transmitted by unmyelinated C fibers
  • ➤ sharp, localized pain is carried by A delta fibers

questions.text: Which of the following sentence is incorrect related to perception of sensory stimuli related to pain:

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated pain response to a innocuous stimulus

options.label: B
options.text: Allodynia is a sensation of pain in response to an innocuous stimulus

options.label: C
options.text: Causalgia is a type of neuropathic pain

questions.correct_answer: A. Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated pain response to a innocuous stimulus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated pain response to a innocuous stimulus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperalgesia = Exaggerated pain response to a noxious (harmful) stimulus . Allodynia = Pain in response to a non-noxious (harmless) stimulus . Causalgia = A type of neuropathic pain seen in nerve injuries .
  • ➤ Hyperalgesia = Exaggerated pain response to a noxious (harmful) stimulus .
  • ➤ Hyperalgesia
  • ➤ noxious (harmful) stimulus
  • ➤ Allodynia = Pain in response to a non-noxious (harmless) stimulus .
  • ➤ Allodynia
  • ➤ non-noxious (harmless) stimulus
  • ➤ Causalgia = A type of neuropathic pain seen in nerve injuries .
  • ➤ Causalgia
  • ➤ neuropathic pain
  • ➤ nerve injuries

questions.text: In the lesion of fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus, which of the following sensations are expected to be affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Proprioceptors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus are part of the posterior column-medial lemniscus pathway, which carries fine touch, proprioception, and vibration. Pain and temperature sensations are transmitted via the lateral spinothalamic tract, not the posterior column.
  • ➤ The fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus are part of the posterior column-medial lemniscus pathway, which carries fine touch, proprioception, and vibration.
  • ➤ Pain and temperature sensations are transmitted via the lateral spinothalamic tract, not the posterior column.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male is evaluated by a physiatrist after a stroke. The patient is observed to suffer from dysmetria, ataxia, and an intention tremor. These neurological signs are most likely related to a lesion within which of the following regions of the brain?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cerebellum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lesions in the cerebellum cause ataxia, dysmetria, and intention tremors , affecting motor coordination without causing muscle weakness .
  • ➤ cerebellum
  • ➤ ataxia, dysmetria, and intention tremors
  • ➤ motor coordination
  • ➤ muscle weakness

questions.text: While studying the stimulus given at different time interval and their responses Pavlov performed various experiment on dogs, in Pavlov’s famous experiment the dog shows which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Conditional response

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Classical conditioning involves learning through association, where a neutral stimulus (bell) becomes a conditioned stimulus after repeated pairings with an unconditioned stimulus (food) , leading to a conditioned response (salivation to the bell alone) .
  • ➤ Classical conditioning
  • ➤ neutral stimulus (bell) becomes a conditioned stimulus
  • ➤ unconditioned stimulus (food)
  • ➤ conditioned response (salivation to the bell alone)

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman is referred to a neurologist by her family physician because of a recent loss of initiative, lethargy, memory problems, and a loss of vision. She is diagnosed with primary hypothyroidism and referred to an endocrinologist for treatment of her thyroid problem. All the following are functions of thyroid cells except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Synthesize thyroid hormones.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The synthesis of T3 and T4 occurs in the colloid , not inside thyroid follicular cells. However, thyroid follicular cells collect iodine, synthesize thyroglobulin, and secrete hormones into circulation .
  • ➤ synthesis of T3 and T4 occurs in the colloid
  • ➤ thyroid follicular cells collect iodine, synthesize thyroglobulin, and secrete hormones into circulation

questions.text: Which of the following regarding actions on plasma Ca++ and PO4- is true:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PTH increases Ca²⁺ and decreases PO₄³⁻ (via renal phosphate excretion). 1,25-DHCC (Calcitriol) increases both Ca²⁺ and PO₄³⁻ (via intestinal absorption). Calcitonin decreases both Ca²⁺ and PO₄³⁻ (by inhibiting bone resorption).
  • ➤ PTH increases Ca²⁺ and decreases PO₄³⁻ (via renal phosphate excretion).
  • ➤ PTH increases Ca²⁺ and decreases PO₄³⁻
  • ➤ 1,25-DHCC (Calcitriol) increases both Ca²⁺ and PO₄³⁻ (via intestinal absorption).
  • ➤ 1,25-DHCC (Calcitriol) increases both Ca²⁺ and PO₄³⁻
  • ➤ Calcitonin decreases both Ca²⁺ and PO₄³⁻ (by inhibiting bone resorption).
  • ➤ Calcitonin decreases both Ca²⁺ and PO₄³⁻

questions.text: A 42-year-old obese female with type 2 DM and hypertension presents to discuss an elevated level of prolactin. She complained of galactorrhea and no menses for two year. The secretion of this hormone is controlled by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dopamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dopamine (Prolactin Inhibitory Factor, PIF) inhibits prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary. A decrease in dopamine leads to hyperprolactinemia, causing galactorrhea and amenorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following graphs represent correct relationship between “mean arterial BP” and “plasma vasopressin(pmol/L)” Abscissa= mean arterial BP; Ordinate= plasma vasopressin:
questions.explanation: Ans. C) C

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the given cystometrogram?

options.label: A
options.text: Segment la is due to residual urine

options.label: B
options.text: Segment II is due to Laplace law

options.label: C
options.text: Micturition fails to happen in segment II

options.label: D
options.text: The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred

questions.correct_answer: B. Segment II is due to Laplace law
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Segment II is due to Laplace Law

questions.text: Which of the following is the diluting segment of kidney?
questions.correct_answer: A. Thick ascending limb of LOH
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thick ascending limb of LOH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (TAL) is the primary diluting segment of the kidney because it actively reabsorbs Na⁺, K⁺, and Cl⁻ but is impermeable to water , leading to the production of dilute urine .
  • ➤ thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (TAL) is the primary diluting segment of the kidney
  • ➤ actively reabsorbs Na⁺, K⁺, and Cl⁻ but is impermeable to water
  • ➤ dilute urine

questions.text: For the following question, Assertion - Constriction of efferent arteriole can decrease GFR. Reason - More than threefold increase in resistance decreases Renal blood flow& increase in colloid osmotic pressure. Mark the correct option as per the following direction: Select one of the following:

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently correct statements, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.

options.label: B
options.text: Assertion is independently a correct statement, but the Reasons is independently an incorrect statement.

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently an incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a correct statement.

options.label: D
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently incorrect statements

questions.correct_answer: A. Both Assertion and Reasons are independently correct statements, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reasons are independently correct statements, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mild to moderate constriction of the efferent arteriole increases GFR, but severe constriction leads to a sharp rise in oncotic pressure, reducing GFR due to decreased renal blood flow.

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect match?

options.label: B
options.text: Motilin - M cells from duodenum and jejunum

options.label: C
options.text: CCK from I cell of duodenum and pancreas

options.label: D
options.text: Secretin from S cells of duodenum and jejunum

questions.correct_answer: B. Motilin - M cells from duodenum and jejunum
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Motilin – M cells from duodenum and jejunum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Motilin is secreted by Mo cells, not M cells , which are involved in immune function rather than hormone secretion.
  • ➤ Mo cells, not M cells
  • ➤ immune function

questions.text: Arrange the parts of the Sarcomere from periphery to center. Z line M line A band H zone
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4, 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sarcomere is organized from the periphery to the center as follows: Z line → A band → H zone → M line .
  • ➤ sarcomere is organized from the periphery to the center as follows: Z line → A band → H zone → M line

questions.text: Which of the following hormones act via JAK- STAT pathway?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Leptin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hormones that use the JAK-STAT pathway include Leptin, Growth Hormone, Prolactin, Erythropoietin, and Cytokines (e.g., IL-6, IFN-γ).
  • ➤ Hormones that use the JAK-STAT pathway include Leptin, Growth Hormone, Prolactin, Erythropoietin, and Cytokines (e.g., IL-6, IFN-γ).

questions.text: Which among the following has the highest airway resistance?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bronchi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mid-sized bronchi (segmental bronchi) have the highest airway resistance due to their moderate diameter and fewer branches.
  • ➤ Mid-sized bronchi (segmental bronchi) have the highest airway resistance due to their moderate diameter and fewer branches.

questions.text: Researcher was studying the effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and change in pH on ventilation, when he simulated the condition of hypoxia and hypercapnia with pH of 7.35 and plotted the graph, which one of the following is the appropriate representation of the given condition.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) B

questions.text: Statement A: The lesion of lateral hypothalamus will result in anorexia Statement B: Hyperphagia is associated with the stimulation of ventromedial hypothalamus Which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The statement A is true, the statement B is false

options.label: B
options.text: The statement A is false, the statement B is true

options.label: C
options.text: Both the statements A and B are true

options.label: D
options.text: Both the statements A and B are false

questions.correct_answer: A. The statement A is true, the statement B is false
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The statement A is true, the statement B is false

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral hypothalamus is the hunger center; its lesion leads to anorexia. The ventromedial hypothalamus is the satiety center; its stimulation suppresses appetite, while its lesion causes hyperphagia.
  • ➤ The lateral hypothalamus is the hunger center; its lesion leads to anorexia.
  • ➤ The ventromedial hypothalamus is the satiety center; its stimulation suppresses appetite, while its lesion causes hyperphagia.

questions.text: Statement A: The deep and visceral pain are better localized compared to the superficial pain. Statement B: There will be a deficiency of A delta fibers in the deep structures compared to superficial structures. Which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The statement A is true, the statement B is false

options.label: B
options.text: The statement A is false, the statement B is true

options.label: C
options.text: Both the statements A and B are true

options.label: D
options.text: Both the statements A and B are false

questions.correct_answer: B. The statement A is false, the statement B is true
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The statement A is false, the statement B is true

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superficial pain is well-localized due to A delta fibers, while deep and visceral pain is poorly localized due to C fibers. Deep and visceral structures have fewer A delta fibers, leading to dull and diffuse pain sensation.
  • ➤ Superficial pain is well-localized due to A delta fibers, while deep and visceral pain is poorly localized due to C fibers.
  • ➤ Deep and visceral structures have fewer A delta fibers, leading to dull and diffuse pain sensation.

questions.text: Assertion: The REM sleep is also termed as paradoxical sleep Reason: During REM sleep, there will be rapid low voltage activities in the EEG like those in aroused state Which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion statement is incorrect, but the reason statement is correct

options.label: D
options.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are incorrect

questions.correct_answer: A. Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ REM sleep is termed paradoxical sleep because EEG resembles wakefulness despite deep sleep. EEG during REM sleep shows low-voltage, high-frequency beta waves, similar to an aroused state. During REM sleep, there is muscle atonia, rapid eye movements, and vivid dreaming.
  • ➤ REM sleep is termed paradoxical sleep because EEG resembles wakefulness despite deep sleep.
  • ➤ EEG during REM sleep shows low-voltage, high-frequency beta waves, similar to an aroused state.
  • ➤ During REM sleep, there is muscle atonia, rapid eye movements, and vivid dreaming.

questions.text: The conversion of short-term memories to long term memories is associated with which of the following structures of the brain?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hippocampus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hippocampus is the key structure involved in converting short-term memories into long-term memories. Long-term potentiation (LTP) in the hippocampus is essential for memory consolidation.
  • ➤ The hippocampus is the key structure involved in converting short-term memories into long-term memories.
  • ➤ Long-term potentiation (LTP) in the hippocampus is essential for memory consolidation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the concentration of chloride ions in the CSF and the blood?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Plasma < CSF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chloride concentration is higher in CSF than in plasma due to active transport by the choroid plexus. This difference helps regulate neuronal excitability and maintain the ionic environment of the brain.
  • ➤ Chloride concentration is higher in CSF than in plasma due to active transport by the choroid plexus.
  • ➤ This difference helps regulate neuronal excitability and maintain the ionic environment of the brain.

questions.text: Statement A: Increased glomerular colloid osmotic pressure will oppose filtration in the glomerulus Statement B: Increased Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure will favor filtration in the glomerulus Which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The statement A is true, the statement B is false

options.label: B
options.text: The statement A is false, the statement B is true

options.label: C
options.text: Both the statements A and B are true

options.label: D
options.text: Both the statements A and B are false

questions.correct_answer: A. The statement A is true, the statement B is false
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The statement A is true, the statement B is false.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Increased glomerular colloid osmotic pressure opposes filtration, whereas increased Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure also opposes (not favors) filtration in the glomerulus.

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph given below?

options.label: A
options.text: A - Glucose, B - PAH, C - Bicarbonate and D - Inulin

options.label: B
options.text: A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH

options.label: C
options.text: A - PAH, B - Inulin, C - Glucose and D - Bicarbonate

options.label: D
options.text: A - Inulin, B - Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D – PAH

questions.correct_answer: B. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH
questions.explanation: Ans. B) A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH

questions.text: Which of the following is/are the component(s) of the counter current multiplier of the countercurrent system? Descending limb of the loop of Henle Thick ascending limb of Henle Thin ascending limb of Henle Vasa recta of the juxtamedullary nephron
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The countercurrent multiplier consists of the descending limb, thin ascending limb, and thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle . The vasa recta is a countercurrent exchanger , helping to maintain the osmotic gradient but not contributing to its formation .
  • ➤ The countercurrent multiplier consists of the descending limb, thin ascending limb, and thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle .
  • ➤ countercurrent multiplier
  • ➤ descending limb, thin ascending limb, and thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle
  • ➤ The vasa recta is a countercurrent exchanger , helping to maintain the osmotic gradient but not contributing to its formation .
  • ➤ vasa recta is a countercurrent exchanger
  • ➤ not contributing to its formation

questions.text: If pH of the blood is 7.8 and PCO2 is 50 mmHg and HCO3 is 30 mMol/liter the most suitable statement is:
questions.correct_answer: D. Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metabolic alkalosis occurs when bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) is increased. Compensation occurs by the respiratory system retaining CO₂ (hypoventilation) to restore acid-base balance. pH determines if it’s acidosis (<7.35) or alkalosis (>7.45). If PCO₂ follows the pH trend, it’s respiratory; if HCO₃⁻ follows the pH, it’s metabolic.
  • ➤ Metabolic alkalosis occurs when bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) is increased.
  • ➤ Metabolic alkalosis occurs when bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) is increased.
  • ➤ Compensation occurs by the respiratory system retaining CO₂ (hypoventilation) to restore acid-base balance.
  • ➤ Compensation occurs by the respiratory system retaining CO₂ (hypoventilation) to restore acid-base balance.
  • ➤ pH determines if it’s acidosis (<7.35) or alkalosis (>7.45).
  • ➤ pH determines if it’s acidosis (<7.35) or alkalosis (>7.45).
  • ➤ If PCO₂ follows the pH trend, it’s respiratory; if HCO₃⁻ follows the pH, it’s metabolic.
  • ➤ If PCO₂ follows the pH trend, it’s respiratory; if HCO₃⁻ follows the pH, it’s metabolic.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient visits a neurologist with a unique concern. The patient reports having difficulty recognizing familiar faces, including those of close family members and friends. This issue has been causing significant social discomfort. Which of the following conditions best describes the patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Prosopagnosia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prosopagnosia is a neurological disorder caused by damage to the fusiform gyrus, leading to difficulty in recognizing faces while other visual and cognitive abilities remain intact.

questions.text: All the following can be seen in lower motor neuron lesions, except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hyperreflexia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperreflexia is a feature of upper motor neuron lesions, not lower motor neuron lesions.
